answers.answer: Hi there!A Rathke's cleft cyst is a benign growth found on the pituitary gland in the brain, specifically a fluid-filled cyst in the posterior portion of the anterior pituitary gland. It is often asymptomatic though occasionally these could lead to symptoms such as visual disturbances, headaches, hormonal issues such as diabetes, galactorrhoea etc.Hope this information is helpful.Take care!

question: What symptoms or problems should one be aware of, with diagnosis of Rathke's cleft cyst, abuting  the infundibulum and right aspect of the optic chiasm?Size shown on MRI to be 8 x 8 x 9, with mild deep white matter microvascular ischemic changes without evidence of acute ischemia.No abnormal parenchymal enhancement is seenVentricles are normal in sizeNo extra axial fluidBasilar cisterns are patentCentral flow voids are maintainedNormal enhancement of the cavernous sinus is seenNo abnormal enhancrment is seen on the whole brain post contrast imagesThis discussion is related to/posts/Neurology/Macro-Prolactinoma-MRI/show/1844936.
title: Rathke's cleft cyst
